course.subject: MATH
course.name: Capstone Project for Data Science
course.description: This is a project-based course that trains students on applying computational and analytical tools (matrix computation, Fourier and wavelet transform, convex optimization, etc.) to real-world data analysis problems (recommendation system, signal processing, computer vision, etc.). Familiarity with a programming language is preferred, such as R, Matlab, or Python. For BSc in Data Science and Technology students only.
course.prerequisites: MATH 3322 AND MATH 3332

reviews.author: dddddddddd
reviews.comment_content:
The content of the course was completely different form previous years since the instructor had changed. Prof Ye used 3 weeks to introduce SVD and sparsity. The remaining weeks are mandatory progress presentations(3 in total).
Most of the reference papers were contributed by her husband Prof Cai. Quite understandable, how else could she condemned our mediocrity up her ivory tower with source codes and shit.
Tips: contact other contributors of your reference paper, they might have the original source codes and other related researches that might inspire you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
These's not much teaching in the course. According to prof Ye, topics like SVD, sparsity and optimization were mentioned in MATH 3332. She did elaborate on those topics, but her notes and accents provided little help understanding the content. She might skim through contents we have no knowledge of since she's unfamiliar of our course pathways.
The TA is real nice tho, he would take the time to help you understand your mission and provide solutions to your inquiries.
reviews.comment_grading:
Can't be that bad in a capstone project, at worst you get a B.
Final exam was opennotes, so bring you printed course notes to the exam. Most of the solutions could be found in those notes.
reviews.comment_workload: The course involves coding, a report, presentation and a final exam. I knew the course would be a cluster-fuck first lesson in when I realized the content of the course has completely changed. What's worse was when she announced there would be a final exam. If you are familiar with python codes and independent research, it should be a piece of cake course to you. Just remember to save some content for every next progress presentation, or else she would accused of providing nothing new.

reviews.author: kinkinkinkin
reviews.comment_content:
Course Website:
https://yao-lab.github.io/capstone/2020.fall/

Nothing related to MATH3322 and MATH3332, although they are the prerequisites.


Lecture 01: History and Overview of Artificial Intelligence.
Lecture 02: Supervised Learning: Linear Regression with Python
Lecture 03: Linear Classification with Python
Lecture 04: Project 1
Lecture 05: Model Assessment and Selection: Subset, Forward, and Backward Selection
Lecture 06: Model Selection: Ridge, Lasso, and Principal Component Regression
Lecture 07: Decision Trees
Lecture 08: Bagging, Random Forests and Boosting
Lecture 09: Support Vector Machines
Lecture 10: Seminar
Lecture 11: Seminar
Lecture 12: Seminar.
Lecture 13: Seminar
Lecture 14: Seminar and Final Project
Lecture 15: An Introduction to Convolutional Neural Networks
Lecture 16: Examples of Convolutional Neural Networks.
Lecture 17: Topics in CNN: Visualization, Transfer Learning
Lecture 18: Topics in CNN: Visualization, Transfer Learning, Neural Style, and Adversarial Examples
Lecture 19: An Introduction to Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) and Long Short Term Memory (LSTM)
Lecture 20: Attention, Transformer and BERT
Lecture 21: Seminar
Lecture 22: Seminar
Lecture 23: Seminar
Lecture 24: Seminar
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good :)

All the lectures and tutorials are optional. You can skip all if you know about it.

Professor will teach you some concept and show you some Python code which is useful for your project.
reviews.comment_grading:
No attendance
No exam
No formal grading scheme.
No score released.

You can form a group to do the project. (1 - 3 people)
You can also do the project individually.

You have to select a dataset to work on it in the project:

1. Kaggle Contest: Predict Survival on the Titanic.
2. Kaggle Contest: Home Credit Default Risk Prediction.
3. Kaggle Contest: Nexperia Image Classification (Second Stage, on-going).


Project 1
- source codes (any programming language is okay, usually Python)
- poster (just 1 PowerPoint slide is okay)
- presentation (no time limit, but usually around 5-15 mins, although professor reserve half of the lesson for each group to present)

Project 2
- source codes
- poster
- presentation
(the requirement is the entirely the same as above)

You can work on the same dataset in both project 1 and project 2, or you may choose a different dataset in project 2.

I think the grading depends on how much work you have done on the 2 projects.

and my final grade is extremely good :)
reviews.comment_workload:
There are only 2 Kaggle projects, and you can finish them very easily in a few days.

Almost zero workloads.
